docs.snippet: SAS Institute, the world's largest private software company, has built its lucrative business by being the pioneer of sophisticated data-analysis tools. SAS software, down to its own programming language, is used by most large corporations for thi...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAS Institute, the world's largest private software company, has built its lucrative business by being the pioneer of sophisticated data-analysis tools. SAS software, down to its own programming language, is used by most large corporations for things like detecting credit card fraud for banks and fine-tuning pricing for retailers. But the data-analysis game is democratizing. New kinds of data are part of the trend, as Web and social-networking messages join all the information in corporate databases as grist of decision making. But so are new tools, opening data-analysis to a wider audience of corporate users, not just elite teams of Ph.D. quants in Fortune 500 companies.
docs.abstract: Bits blog notes the SAS Institute introduces SAS Visual Analytics data-analysis tool. (M)3

docs.abstract: SAS Institute, a traditional leader in data analysis software, has looked vulnerable to challenges that include a host of new rivals and fast-changing technology. But the company has rewritten its software, adopted it for cloud computing and developed easy-to-use visual tools.

headline.main: The Nimble Dance of a Rich Legacy Software Company

docs.snippet: SAS is making its bid on Thursday to grab a share of the widening market for data-analysis tools with a new product, SAS Visual Analytics. It takes mountains of data from corporate databases or Web sources and presents it as easy-to-read charts, g...
docs.abstract: SAS is making its bid on Thursday to grab a share of the widening market for data-analysis tools with a new product, SAS Visual Analytics. It takes mountains of data from corporate databases or Web sources and presents it as easy-to-read charts, graphs and data maps.
